rev.comment: Splitting the Timeline of the "Before Mubarak's resignation" part to [[2011 Egyptian revolution (pre-Mubarak's resignation)]] as per [[Talk:Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution|talk page]]
rev.diff:
Line 1: Line 1: â
{{Split-apart|date=February 2011}}
  â  
{{Politics of Egypt}}
{{Politics of Egypt}}
Line 6: Line 4:
== Before Mubarak's resignation ==
== Before Mubarak's resignation ==
â
{{Split section|date=February 2011}}
+
{{main|Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution (pre-Mubarak's resignation)}}
â
===25 January â Day of Revolt===
+
'''25 January 2011''': The '''"Day of Revolt"''', nationwide protests against the government of Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak began. Tens of thousands of protestors gathered in Cairo, with thousands more in cities throughout Egypt. The protests were generally non-violent, but there were reports of some casualties among both civilians and police.
â
[[File:Day of Anger marchers with out signs.jpg|thumb|Protesters marching to [[Midan Tahrir|Tahrir Square]], in [[Downtown Cairo]], where the main protests were being held]]
  â   â
On 25 January 2011, known as the "'''Day of Revolt'''" ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|yawm al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'', {{IPA-arz|ËjoËm elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref name="ERSAFVZSD" /> or the '''"Day of Anger"''',<ref name="bbc25jan" /> protests took place in cities across Egypt, including [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], [[Suez]] and [[IsmaÃ¯lia]].<ref name="bbc25jan" /> The day was selected as such by the ''[[6 April Youth Movement]]'', ''We Are All Khaled Said Movement'', ''[[National Association for Change]]'', ''25 January Movement'' and ''[[Kefaya]]''<ref name="nyt-fahim">{{Cite news|first=Kareem|last=Fahim|coauthors=El-Nagaar, Mona|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/26/world/middleeast/26egypt.html|title=Violent Clashes Mark Protests Against Mubarakâs Rule|work=The New York Times | date=25 January 2011| accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/6-april-movement-calls-protest-against-police-abuse-0|title=6 April movement calls for protest against police abuse |work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=20 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> to coincide with [[National Police Day (Egypt)|National Police Day]]. Thousands protested in Cairo, with 15,000 occupying [[Tahrir Square]]<ref name="ERSAFVZSD">{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egyptians-report-poor-communication-services-day-anger-1|title=Egyptians Report Poor Communication Services on Day of Anger|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref> (Liberation Square), 20,000 in various locations across Alexandria,<ref name="Egyptians tests Tunisia's Twitter revolution">{{cite web|author=Manthorpe, Jonathan|url=http://www.vancouversun.com/news/Egyptians+tests+Tunisia+Twitter+revolution/4168694/story.html|title=Egyptians Test Tunisia's Twitter Revolution|work=[[The Vancouver Sun]]|date=26 January 2011|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref> 200 demonstrators in the southern city of [[Aswan]], 2,000 in the eastern city of IsmaÃ¯lia, and about 3,000 in the northern city of [[El-Mahalla El-Kubra]].<ref name="Thousands protests in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Ahmed, Amir|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/01/25/egypt.protests/|title=Thousands Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=25 January 2011|accessdate=25 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[File:Day of Anger riot police close.jpg|thumb|left|Paramilitary riot police of the [[Central Security Forces]]; 20,000 to 30,000 police were deployed in central Cairo.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.english.rfi.fr/africa/20110125-egyptian-protesters-say-tunisia-solution |title=Egyptian protesters say Tunisia is the solution |publisher=RFI |date=25 January 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> ]]
  â   â
Cairo protesters had gathered in the morning in front of the High Court in the centre of Cairo. The demonstration was larger than expected and able to break the security cordon and head to [[Tahrir Square]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.addustour.com/ViewTopic.aspx?ac=\ArabicAndInter\2011\01\ArabicAndInter_issue1200_day27_id299121.htm |title=3 ÙØªÙÙ ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙÙÙ Ø§ÙØ«Ø§ÙÙ ÙØªØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ± |work=Al Dustour |language=Arabic |date= 27 January 2011 |accessdate=7 February 2011}}</ref> Police used tear gas and water cannons against the protesters, who in turn threw stones at police, eventually forcing them to retreat.<ref name="bbc25jan">{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-12272836| title=Egypt Protests: Three Killed in 'Day of Revolt'| accessdate=26 January 2011| date=25 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]}}</ref> Deadly clashes broke out during the protests. A policeman was reported to have died in Cairo, while in Suez two protesters were killed.<ref name="bbc25jan" /> It was reported that many police had also been restrained in their use of violence.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70O2GG20110125?sp=true|title=Q+A-How Will Egypt's Protests Affect Mubarak's Rule?|work=[[Reuters]]|date=9 February 2009|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===26 January===
  â
On 26 January riots continued, with protesters numbering in the thousands, although no accurate estimate has yet been made. There was increased use of violence from both protesters and the police, with one protester and one police official killed in Cairo.<ref name="np26jan" /> Suez experienced a dramatic uprising; many protesters were fired upon with live ammunition, and both protesters and police were beaten. Protesters in Suez also managed to set fire to several government buildings, including the police station.<ref name="np26jan">{{cite web|url=http://www.nationalpost.com/news/world/More+casualties+protests+escalate+Egypt/4173057/story.html|title=More Casualties as Protests Escalate in Egypt|work=[[National Post]]|date=22 December 2010|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="aljazeera-448">{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police post|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=27 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112617427113878.html|title=Clinton Calls for reform in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=26 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===27 January===
  â
[[File:Demonstration in Imaba, Cario.jpg|thumb|left|A demonstration in Cairo. The sign has an [[open source]] [[:File:Hosni Mubarak getting the boot.png|caricature]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] which features [[shoeing]].]]
  â
Protests were not as large on 27 January as preparations were made for planned large-scale events on the following day (Friday). The Muslim Brotherhood declared full support for the protests, and members planned to take part during Friday's demonstrations.<ref name="fox-brotherhood">{{Cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2011/01/27/egypts-protests-pose-threat-regime/|title=Egypt's Ruling Party Offers No Concessions to Anti-Government Protesters|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Fox News]]'')|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> Reformer and leader of the [[National Association for Change]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] returned on that day at Cairo International Airport to join the planned protests on the next day.<ref name="BaradeiArrive">{{cite news|last=Elmeshad|first=Mohamed|title=Back in Egypt, ElBaradei vows to take part in planned Friday demonstrations|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/back-egypt-elbaradei-vows-take-part-planned-friday-demonstrations|accessdate=5 February 2011|newspaper=Al Masry Al Youm|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Later in the day a protester of [[Bedouin]] descent was shot dead by police in the town of Sheikh Zoweid in the [[North Sinai Governorate|North Sinai region]], bringing the death toll to seven.<ref name="reuters1">{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1Y520110127|title=Egypt Police Shoot Bedouin Protester Dead|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref name="egypt1">{{Cite news|url=http://news.egypt.com/en/2011012713463/news/-egypt-news/egypt-police-shoot-bedouin-protester-dead.html|title=Egypt Police Shoot Bedouin Protester Dead|publisher=Egypt.com News|date=27 January 2011}}</ref> In Suez, the uprising continued and violence increased as more buildings were set on fire, including police posts. The population of Suez and the Sinai region armed themselves with guns leading to violent revolts by protesters.<ref name="aljazeera-448" />
  â
{{quotebox|âThe people have broken the barrier of fear. There is no going back.â|Mohammed El Baradei<ref name="BaradeiArrive" />}}
  â   â
Hundreds of people were arrested at the various protests across Egypt. More than 120 people were arrested in [[Asyut]], most of whom were members of the Muslim Brotherhood, and about another 600 people were arrested in Cairo, including 8 Egyptian journalists protesting against the government's reported restrictions on domestic and Middle Eastern affairs.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/egyptian-riots-4/story-fn6s850w-1225995176163 |title=4 Confirmed Dead in Egyptian Riots |publisher=''[[Agence France-Presse]]'' (via ''[[Herald Sun]]'') |date=27 January 2011 |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â
{{clear}}
  â   â
===28 January â Friday of Anger===
  â
{{External media
  â
| video1 = {{YouTube|CAaTt-ekDw4&sk|A large car runs over protesters in Cairo}}
  â
| video2 = {{YouTube|CHRHcLWmk0Y|A police car runs over protesters in Cairo)}}
  â
| video3 = {{YouTube|IkTWs7ii124|Egyptian protester shot dead in Alexandria}}
  â
| video4 = {{YouTube|4XnhHzs91MY|Raw Video: Man Shot in Egypt Protest}}
  â
}}
  â   â
Thousands filled the streets across Egypt on Friday 28 January,<ref name="Friday of Anger">{{registration required|date=February 2011}} {{cite web|url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/be97d4a8-2b0b-11e0-a65f-00144feab49a.html#axzz1CMDTT7Ao|title=Pent-Up Anger Bursts on to Cairo Streets|accessdate=28 January 2011|date=28 January 2011|work=[[Financial Times]] }}</ref> called by some the "Friday of Anger" ({{lang-ar|Ø¬ÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØºØ¶Ø¨}} ''{{transl|ar|DIN|Ç§umÊ¿at al-Ä¡aá¸ab}}'' {{IPA-arz|ËgomÊet elËÉ£ÉdÉb<!--no [dË¤] in Egyptian Arabic-->|lang}})<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Andrew Sullivan|Sullivan, Andrew]]|url=http://andrewsullivan.theatlantic.com/the_daily_dish/2011/01/awaiting-the-friday-of-anger.html|title=Awaiting the 'Friday Of Anger'|publisher=''[[The Daily Dish]]'' ([[blog]] of ''[[The Atlantic]]'')|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> and by others as the "Day of Rage".<ref>Issacharoff, Avi (28 January 2011). [http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/egypt-anti-government-protesters-declare-friday-day-of-rage-1.339629 "Egypt Anti-Government Protesters Declare Friday 'Day of Rage']. ''[[Haaretz]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41288680/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/ "Egypt Protesters, Police Brace for 'Day of Rage'"]. 27 January 2011. ''[[MSNBC]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Shortly before 1:00, hours ahead of the expected massive anti-government protests, the Egyptian government shut down internet services,<ref name="aljazeera-272">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html|title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.arabist.net/blog/2011/1/28/urgent-egypt-has-shut-off-the-internet.html|title=Urgent: Egypt Has Shut Off the Internet|publisher=Arabist|last=El Amrani|first=Issandr|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=18 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.readwriteweb.com/hack/2011/01/egypt-tor-use-skyrocketing-as.php|title=Egypt: Tor Use Skyrocketing as Users Route-Around Internet Blocks|work=[[ReadWriteWeb]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> although some people were still able to communicate using a text-to-speech telephone service set up by [[Google]] and [[Twitter]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.businessandleadership.com/technology/item/28137-google-twitter-launch-alte|title=Google, Twitter launch alternative service in Egypt |work=[[Business and Leadership]]|date=|accessdate=12 February 2011}}</ref> Text messaging and mobile phone services also appeared to be blocked.<ref>{{Cite news|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html?hpt=T1&iref=BN1|title=Violent Clashes Erupt During Protests in Egypt|work=[[CNN]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> According to [[Vodafone]], all mobile phone operators in Egypt were instructed to suspend services in selected areas. Under Egyptian legislation the authorities have the right to issue such an order and the operators are obliged to comply.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vodafone.com/content/index/press.html|title=Press|publisher=[[Vodafone]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref>
  â
[[File:Mohandeseen protests.jpg|thumb|left|The up-scale [[Mohandessin|Mohandeseen]] district in [[Giza]] during the Friday of Anger. Violent clashes occurred here between the protesters and the security forces which occupied the bridge on the left, involving stone-throwing, [[Molotov cocktails]], rubber bullets and tear gas grenades.]]
  â   â
[[File:Destroyed Central Security Forces vehicle.jpg|thumb|Police vehicle that was burned during the night of 28 January]]
  â   â
Shortly after [[Friday prayers]], tens of thousands of Egyptians began the protests, and within hours the number rose to the hundreds of thousands. Potential [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|presidential candidate]] [[Mohamed ElBaradei]] traveled from [[Giza]], where he had been leading protests, to Cairo,<ref name="ElBaradei to join Egypt protest">{{cite web|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/ElBaradei-to-join-Egypt-protest-20110127|archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5w6N48d0H|archivedate=29 January 2011|title=ElBaradei To Join Egypt Protest|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[News24]]}}</ref><ref name="Mohamed ElBaradei: There's no going back">{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/27/elbaradei-return-cairo-egypt|title=Mohamed ElBaradei: There's No Going Back|accessdate=27 January 2011|date=27 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] }}</ref> where he was arrested at an anti-government rally<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4020436,00.html|title=Report: ElBaradei Arrested in Egypt|work=[[Ynetnews]]|date=|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> and placed under house arrest,<ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.blogs.cnn.com/2011/01/28/clashes-erupt-in-cairo-elbaradei-told-to-stay-put-cnn-camera-confiscated/| title=Unrest in Egypt: Mubarak Expected To Speak; Curfew Imposed in Major Cities| accessdate=28 January 2011|work=[[CNN]]}}</ref> although ElBaradei told Al Jazeera that he was unaware of his house arrest.<ref name="ajprotestersback">{{Cite news| url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112974149942894.html| title=Protesters Back on Egypt Streets| accessdate=29 January 2011| date=29 January 2011|publisher=Al Jazeera English}}</ref>
  â   â
[[File:Al jazeera 2011 egypt protests.ogv|thumb|An [[Al Jazeera]] report on the protests (in English)]]
  â   â
Throughout the day, police fired [[tear gas]], [[rubber bullets]], and [[water cannon]]s into crowds during violent clashes between authorities and anti-government protesters in Cairo, Alexandria, and throughout Egypt.<ref name="cnn-crackdown">{{Cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/01/28/egypt.protests/index.html|title=Egypt Cracks Down on Mass Protests|work=[[CNN]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=28 January 2011}}</ref> Thousands in Suez stormed and took control of a police station, freed all of the protesters held under arrest there and then [[torched up]] a nearby smaller local police post.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112734210243448.html|title=Protesters Torch Egypt Police Post|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]}}</ref><ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net">{{Cite news|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/28/friday-protests-liveblog|title=Live Blog â Egypt's Protests Erupt|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> In [[Port Said]] tens of thousands of protesters gathered and multiple government buildings were set ablaze.<ref name="blogs.aljazeera.net" /> In Suez, police shot and killed at least one man taking part in the protests.<ref name="globemail" /> The government issued a 18:00 to 7:00 the next day curfew, but protesters ignored it and were met by police.<ref name="globemail">{{Cite news| url=http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/egypt-protests-demand-mubaraks-ouster-army-imposes-curfew/article1886184/| title=Egypt Protests Demand Mubarak's Ouster; Army Imposes Curfew| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[The Globe and Mail]]}}</ref> In the evening, one of the [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] (NDP) headquarters buildings in Cairo;<ref>''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' live broadcast, 16:23 UTC</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31028059540819968|title=NDP's Headquarters Up in Flames|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> was set on fire, and the culprit is still unknown. While protesters paused for evening prayers, police continued firing tear gas.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://twitter.com/#!/AJELive/status/31032922240716801|title=Tear Gas Canisters Were Fired|publisher=''[[Al Jazeera English]]'' (via [[Twitter]])|date=28 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The Egyptian government deployed military in [[Cairo]], [[Alexandria]], and [[Suez]] to assist the police.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/01/28/world/main7293753.shtml|title=Cairo Crowds Overpower Police; Army Deployed|work=[[CBS News]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011128151048463975.html|title='Army Out' in Egyptian Capital|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=28 January 2011}}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] reported that in Suez the military wanted to avoid an open armed confrontation with protesters.<ref name="asianews1">{{cite web|url=http://www.asianews.it/news-en/Cairo:-anti-Mubarak-protests-continue,-at-least-50-dead-from-clashes-20637.html|title=Egypt Cairo: Anti-Mubarak Protests Continue, at Least 50 Dead from Clashes |publisher=Asianews.it|date=|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> The same was reported in Alexandria.
  â   â
Protestors gathered in front of the l-Istiqama Mosque in Giza.<ref name="chron1">{{cite web|url=http://www.chron.com/news/photogallery/Violent_protests_in_Egypt.html|title=Violent Protests in Egypt|work=[[Houston Chronicle]] |date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Rebels and riot police fought in parts of Giza, including at the mosque.<ref name="G01">{{cite web|last=Weaver|first=Matthew|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/jan/28/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Protests in Egypt â As They Happened|work=[[The Guardian]] |location=UK|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
A delegation led by the chief of staff of Egypt's armed forces, Lt. Gen. Sami Hafez Enan, was in Washington, D.C., when the visit was truncated due to the protests. The sessions, an annual country-to-country military coordination, were being led for the U.S. by Assistant Secretary of Defense for International Security Affairs [[Alexander Vershbow]]. A meeting with Adm. [[Mike Mullen]], chairman of the U.S. [[Joint Chiefs of Staff]], and other talks had been planned to extend to 2 February. However, in light of events in Egypt, the delegation left Washington to return home.<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} [[Elisabeth Bumiller|Bumiller, Elisabeth]] (28 January 2011). [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/29/world/middleeast/29military-egypt.html?hp "Egyptian Military Chiefs Cut Pentagon Visit Short"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. Retrieved 28 January 2011.</ref> Before their departure Friday night, Vershbow urged the two dozen representatives of the largely American-funded Egyptian military "to exercise 'restraint'".<ref>{{registration required|date=February 2011}} Bumiller, Elisabeth; Mark Landler contributed reporting, [http://www.nytimes.com/2011/01/30/world/middleeast/30military.html "Calling for Restraint, Pentagon Faces Test of Influence With Ally"]. ''[[The New York Times]]''. 29 January 2011 (30 January 2011, p. A1, New York edition). Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
  â   â
''Al Jazeera'' reported an ''[[Associated Press]]'' claim that an elite counterterrorism force that had been deployed at strategic points around [[Cairo]], and that Egypt's interior ministry was warning of "decisive measures". The secretary-general of the ruling National Democratic Party, [[Safwat Sherif]], held a press conference stating, "We hope that tomorrow's Friday prayers and its rituals happen in a quiet way that upholds the value of such rituals ... and that no one jeopardises the safety of citizens or subjects them to something they do not want."<ref name="aljazeera2">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201112810059478272.html |title=Fresh Protests Erupt in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â
[[File:NDP HQ on fire.jpg|thumb|left|The main headquarters of the ruling [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|National Democratic Party]] aflame during ''Friday of Anger'' in Cairo]]
  â   â
Amid reports of looting of government buildings, concerns were raised about the safety of the antiquities of the famous [[Egyptian Museum]], near the epicenter of the protests in Cairo. Egyptian state TV announced in the evening that army commandos had secured the museum.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Army Secures Museum with Pharaonic Treasures|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/28/arts-us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70R7K820110128|work=[[Reuters]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters joined soldiers in protecting the [[Egyptian Museum]], situated beside the burning ruling party headquarters.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-291-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Jan 29 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=4 January 2011}}</ref> Looters managed to enter during the night from the roof to damage a number of small artifacts, and it was initially reported that they had ripped the heads off two mummies, but subsequent reports claimed that Egypt's top archaeologist had mistaken skulls from other skeletons, and that the mummies were intact.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Looters Destroy Mummies in Egyptian Museum|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/2011/01/29/us-egypt-museum-idUKTRE70S1YU20110129|work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author=Torchia, Christopher|title=AP Interview: Egypt Declares Treasures Safe|url=http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/M/ML_EGYPT_PROTEST_ANTIQUITIES?SITE=TNKNN&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT|publisher=''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[Knoxville News Sentinel]]'')|date=1 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The detention of ElBaradei prompted the U.S. to review its $1.5 billion aid package for Egypt; he was later released.<ref name="G01" /> The day's defiance was summed up by the plethora of [[Tunisia]]n national flags and anti-Mubarak [[graffiti]] that the protesters had created in the [[Greater Cairo]] region, Alexandria, Beni Suef, Mansoura and Manufiya.<ref name="chron1" /> Meanwhile, the [[Muslim Brotherhood]] said that twenty members of the banned group had been detained overnight, including Essam El-Erian, its main spokesman, and Mohammed Moursi, one of its leaders.<ref name="aljazeera2" />
  â   â
The arson and looting that took place throughout the day has been compared to the disorder that befell Cairo during the [[Cairo Fire|1952 fire]], also known as Black Saturday.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Muhammad |first=Mohsen |date=3 February 2011 |title=Ø®Ø³Ø§Ø±Ø© |trans_title=Khusara |journal=[[Al Gomhuria]] |language=Arabic |accessdate=2011-02-06 |url=http://www.alarabiya.net/views/2011/02/03/136071.html |format=Reprint}}</ref>
  â   â
===29 January===
  â
[[File:Demonstrators on Army Truck in Tahrir Square, Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators standing on an army vehicle in [[Tahrir Square]], Cairo. The sign reads: "Leave, you tyrant. Down with Mubarak."]]
  â   â
The night of 28/29 January was quieter in Cairo with fewer reports of looting than in previous days.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 â Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Multiple and widespread protests continued, with many protesters chanting, "Down with Mubarak". Chants of "the people and the army are one" were also heard, as the position of the army in the course of events continued to be critical but ambiguous.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm" /> By 2:00 pm local time, approximately 50,000 people had gathered in [[Tahrir Square]], 10,000 gathered in Kafr-al-Sheikh, and additional protests were held throughout Egypt.<ref>Al Jazeera English live broadcast, 12:15 UTC, 29 January</ref> A curfew was announced by the army for Cairo, Alexandria and Suez from 4 â 6 pm. The 6:00 pm police curfew the previous day had had "almost no effect whatsoever", according to ''[[Al Jazeera English]]'', and protesters continued to descend on Tahrir Square.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm" /> Protesters also gathered at the [[Ministry of Interior (Egypt)|Ministry of Interior]], and three of them were killed by police when they tried to storm the building.<ref name="reuterslive">{{cite web| url=http://live.reuters.com/Event/Unrest_in_Egypt| title=Unrest in Egypt| accessdate=28 January 2011| date=28 January 2011| work=[[Reuters]]}}</ref>
  â   â
Protesters were described by reporters as more confident than the previous day and earlier, and even celebratory as they felt they were nearing their objectiveâthe end of Mubarak's presidencyâalthough they had no tangible evidence that it was coming about.<ref name="AlJazeera29th1pm" /> An eyewitness told Al Jazeera that people of all ages, men and women were present. Despite the curfew, people were on the streets and no one was attempting to stop them. Looting was also reported, while no police were visible on Cairo's streets.<ref>[http://www.newsmax.com/Newsfront/egypt-protests-hosni-mubarak/2011/01/29/id/384360 "Egyptian Protesters Defy Curfew Again"]. 29 January 2011. ''[[Newsmax]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref>
  â   â
[[File:Protesters marching in Cairo - 29JAN2011.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Cairo]]
  â   â
In [[Beni Suef]], south of Cairo, 17 protesters were shot dead by police as they attempted to attack two police stations in the city. Eight more people were killed during protests in the city. In the Abu Zabaal prison in Cairo, eight people were killed as police clashed with inmates trying to escape. According to a ''[[Reuters]]'' tally, these deaths bring the total death toll to at least 100; however, no figures could be accurately confirmed.<ref name="reuters3">{{cite news|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70S0LX20110129|title=Update 1-Death Toll in Egypt's Protests Tops 100 â Sources |work=[[Reuters]]|date=29 January 2009|accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> Inmates rioted in Cairo's [[Wadi Natrun]] prison as it was attacked by an angry mob leading to the escape of several [[Islamist]] [[terrorists]] and others.<ref>{{cite web|author=Bradley, John R.|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/debate/article-1352090/EGYPT-RIOTS-Hosni-Mubarak-beware-comes-next.html#ixzz1ChE3Srqm|title=Egypt Riots: Hosni Mubarak Must Go, But Beware What Comes Next |work=[[Daily Mail]]|date=18 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Prison overcrowding and [[police brutality]] were one of the complaints voiced by many of the protesters in urban Egypt.<ref name="reuters3" /> Emad Gad, an analyst with the [[Al-Ahram Center for Political and Strategic Studies]], said that he has obtained information from a trustworthy source that "there have been orders from the very top to free known [[Felony|felons]] from the prisons, to arm them and to let them mingle with protesters."<ref name="Spiegel Anarchy">{{Cite news|last1=Steinvorth|first1=Daniel|last2=Windfuhr|first=Volkhard|work=[[Der Spiegel]] |title=Mubarak will Ãgypten brennen sehen|trans_title=Mubarak Wants To See Egypt Burn|language=[[German language|German]]|date=30 January 2011|url=http://www.spiegel.de/politik/ausland/0,1518,742498,00.html|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Two Egyptian policemen jailed following the death of anti-corruption activist Khaled Said were among the hundreds of prisoners that escaped in Cairo that day.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/egypt-rights-advocates-report-protest-death-toll-as-high-as-300.html|title=Egypt: Rights Advocates Report Protest Death Toll as High as 300}}</ref>
  â   â
Tanks were reported on the streets of Suez. A police station was torched after protesters seized weapons stored inside before telling officers to get out. At first there was a presence of the Central Security Force, then army troops who were ordered into major cities to quell street fighting.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|author=Parker, Nick|url=http://www.thesun.co.uk/sol/homepage/news/3378537/Troops-battle-rioters-in-Egypt.html?OTC-RSS&ATTR=News|title=Troops Battle Rioters in Egypt|work=[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]|date=29 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> In the [[Sinai]] town of [[Rafah]] a [[lynch mob]] killed three police officers.<ref name="autogenerated2" /><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.heraldsun.com.au/ipad/pyramids-closed-as-egypts-deadly-protests-spread/story-fn6s850w-1225996772657|title=Pyramids Closed as Deadly Riots Spread|work=[[Herald Sun]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Many tourists sites have been disrupted, with access to the [[Pyramids]] in [[Giza]] suspended.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Egypt Closes Off Access to Famed Pyramids, Other Sites, as Protests Enter Fifth Day|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/106554/20110129/egypt-mubarak.htm|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[International Business Times]]|date=29 January 2011<!-- 9:31 am EST-->}}</ref> The resort town of [[Sharm-el Shaikh]], however, has been calm.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Wingfield-Hayes|first=Rupert|title=No Sense of Any Crisis in Sharm El-Sheikh|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/12320129|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref> Chaos had been reported at [[Cairo International Airport]], where thousands of stranded and frightened foreigners are attempting to be evacuated back to their home countries.<ref name="english.aljazeera.net">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|title=Egypt Protesters Increase Pressure|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===30 January===
  â
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - graffiti on military vehicle.jpg|thumb|left|A [[Armoured personnel carrier|troop carrier]] defaced with protester graffiti, the larger of which reads "Down with Mubarak", "No to Mubarak", "Mubarak the dictator has fallen" and "Leave, you thief!"]]
  â   â
Overnight, thousands of protesters continued to defy the [[curfew]] and, as the night progressed, troops and armoured vehicles were deployed across Cairo to guard key places such as train stations, major government buildings and banks. The army had insufficient capacity to patrol neighbourhoods, so residents set up [[vigilante]] groups armed with guns, clubs and knives to drive off looters and robbers.<ref name="sky-2011-01-30">{{Cite news|title=Egypt Protests: Vice-President Sworn In|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-President-Mubarak-Appoints-His-First-Vice-President-Omar-Suleiman-Amid-New-Protests/Article/201003415918069?lpos=World_News_Top_Stories_Header_0&lid=ARTICLE_15918069_Egypt%3A_President_Mubarak_Appoints_His_First_Vice-President_Omar_Suleiman_Amid_New_Protests|work=[[Sky News]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> A heavy army presence (though no police) was also reported in Suez.<!--from tv--> Chaos was also rampant in Suez the previous night, but as day broke the streets remained relatively quiet. As in Cairo, many residents formed vigilante groups to protect their homes and businesses in the absence of police. The military set up numerous checkpoints throughout the city.<ref>{{Cite news|title=ElBaradei: No Going Back in Egypt|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130165636218719.html|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> About another 30 dead bodies were taken to El Damardash Hospital in central Cairo. The figure included 2 children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allvoices.com/contributed-news/8036654-rising-death-toll-in-egypt-protests-cairo-25-suez-38-alexandria-36|title=Rising Death Toll in Egypt Protests: Cairo 25; Suez 38; Alexandria 36}}</ref>
  â
[[File:EAF F-16 during protests.jpg|thumb|right|One of two [[Egyptian Air Force]] [[F-16]]s that flew over Cairo during the military's show of strength on 30 January]]
  â   â
By 6:00 am local time, Tahrir Square was quiet, with only a few hundred people.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/29/live-blog-301-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 30/1 â Egypt Protests|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Later in the morning, 3,000â5,000 protesters were reported as gathering there, including hundreds of state judges protesting for the first time.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan" /><ref>[http://twitter.com/nolanjazeera Dan Nolan @nolanjazeera].</ref><ref name="Egypt's opposition discusses interim government">{{Cite news|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-opposition-discusses-interim-government|title=Egypt's Opposition Discusses Interim Government|work=[[Almasry Alyoum]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> They, among others, have called for a new [[Constitution of Egypt|constitution]] and a [[transitional government]].
  â   â
Soldiers were then given orders to use [[live ammunition]], but the army said the order would be refused since they were present to "protect the people". According to ''Al Jazeera Arabic'', the army chief told protesters they would not be fired upon. Helicopters were monitoring the protests, and [[fighter jet]]s were repeatedly flying low over Tahrir Square.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113033817859936.html|title=Cairo Protesters Stand Their Ground|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> After the first pass of the two [[Egyptian Air Force]] [[F-16]]s, the crowd cheered but subsequent passes triggered louder chants, laughing, and waving. The crowd did not disperse.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.usatoday.com/news/world/2011-01-30-egypt-protests_N.htm|title=Egyptian Demonstrations Calm Down|work=[[USA Today]]|last=Michaels|first=Jim|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> Protesters were also reported picking up garbage in Tahrir Square, as essential services were not working and that they wanted to "keep our country clean". Food and water were offered at the scene.<ref>{{Cite news|last=Topol|first=Sarah A.|title=The Anti-Mubarak Love Train|url=http://www.tnr.com/article/world/82454/egypt-riots-mubarak-violence-peaceful|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The New Republic]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[File:2011 Egypt protests - sitting line of men.jpg|thumb|Protesters in Tahrir Square. Translation reads "Go away Mubarak"]]
  â   â
[[Mohamed Hussein Tantawi]], Egypt's Minister of Defence and Commander in Chief of the Egyptian Armed Forces, was seen with the protesters in Tahrir Square in downtown Cairo.<ref name="almasryalyoum1">{{cite web|url=http://www.almasryalyoum.com/en/news/egypts-minister-defense-joins-protesters-tahrir-square|title=Egypt's Minister of Defense Joins Protesters in Tahrir Square |work=[[Al-Masry Al-Youm]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> As of 18:30, Mohammed ElBaradei had arrived in Tahrir Square and told that crowd that "what we have begun cannot go back".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/2011130165636218719.html|title=ElBaradei: No Going Back in Egypt |work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> He also said "You are the owners of this revolution. You are the future. Our key demand is the departure of the regime and the beginning of a new Egypt in which each Egyptian lives in virtue, freedom and dignity."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110130/D9L2RQ980.html|title=Egypt Military Steps Up Presence in Chaotic Cairo|publisher=Apnews.myway.com|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> An opposition leader{{Who|date=January 2011}} said that talks would not be held with Mubarak but only with the army.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/01/arab-satelite-network-al-jazeera-has-reported-that-egyptian-opposition-leaders-say-that-their-negotiations-for-a-transition.html|title=Egypt: Opposition Plans To Negotiate with Military, Not President |work=[[Los Angeles Times]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Mubarak was holding a meeting with his military commanders at the time.<ref>{{cite web|last=Salama|first=Vivian|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/mubarak-meets-military-commanders-as-protesters-looters-disregard-curfew.html|title=Mubarak Meets Military Commanders as Protesters, Looters Disregard Curfew|work=[[Bloomberg]]|date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The Muslim Brotherhood, along with the April 6 Youth Movement, "We are all Khaled Said", National Association for Change, Jan 25 Movement and Kefaya (the main organizers of the protests) gave their support to Mohammed ElBaradei to act as a negotiator in the formation of a temporary national unity government.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12320200|title=Egypt Protests: ElBaradei Tells Crowd 'Change Coming'|work=[[BBC News]]|date=30 January 2011|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Hanegbi |first=Tzachi |url=http://www.jpost.com/MiddleEast/Article.aspx?id=205916&R=R3 |title=ElBaradei Joins Protesters in Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[The Jerusalem Post]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Coker|first=Margaret|url=http://online.wsj.com/article/SB10001424052748704832704576114132934597622.html?mod=googlenews_wsj|title=Egypt's Muslim Brotherhood Backs ElBaradei Role|work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=|accessdate=30 January 2011}}</ref> [[Al Jazeera]] reported that 34 members of the Muslim Brotherhood were released from custody as their guards abandoned their posts.<ref name="Cairo standoff">{{Cite news|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|title=Egypt Protesters in Cairo Standoff|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/201113033817859936.html|accessdate=30 January 2011|date=30 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
President Mubarak asked the current aviation minister and former chief of Air Staff [[Ahmed Shafiq]], to form a new government. Shafiq, a party loyalist, had often been mentioned as a [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|potential successor to Mubarak]] due to his politically reliable nature.<ref name="sky-2011-01-30" />
  â   â
The Egyptian Central Bank said all banks and the stock market would remain closed on Sunday, 30 January.<ref name="bloombergclose">Haroutunian, Mourad; Namatalla, Ahmed A. (29 January 2011). [http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-30/egyptian-bourse-banks-will-be-closed-today-state-tv-reports.html "Egyptian Bourse, Banks Will Stay Closed Today After Anti-Mubarak Protests"]. ''[[Bloomberg]]''. Retrieved 30 January 2011.</ref> Police returned to the streets at about 10:30 pm except at Tahrir Square.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan" /> By 10:55 local time, Al Jazeera's offices in Cairo were ordered to be closed. At the same time, all correspondents for the network had their credentials revoked.<ref name="aj-liveblog30jan" />
  â   â
On the night of 30 January Mubarak's [[Sharm el-Sheikh]] holiday villa was guarded by a small force of armed and loyal police who turned away all approaching vehicles.<ref name="telegraph1">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/8290760/Locals-in-Sharm-el-Sheikh-convinced-Mubarak-is-holed-up-there.html|title=Locals in Sharm-el-Sheikh convinced Mubarak is holed up there}}</ref> Sharm el-Sheikh had seen no deaths and only a minimal amount of trouble.<ref name="telegraph1" /> A number of [[military aircraft]] were visible from the local airportâs perimeter fence, although the airport is frequently used by the armed forces for operations.<ref name="telegraph1" /> It was also one of the hubs for private air travel in and around Egypt, but most [[light aircraft]] had left the airport earlier in the day.<ref name="telegraph1" />
  â   â
===31 January===
  â
The night of 30 January to 31 January was quieter in Cairo, with fewer reports of looting.<ref name="Live blog 30/1 - Egypt protests" /> For the fourth day in a row the curfew was violated without repercussions. Security officials had announced that the curfew would start at 3:00 pm and threatened to shoot anyone who ignored it, although eventually little or no action was taken<ref name="Rian30">{{Cite news|last=Tomasevic|first=Goran|title=Curfew Hours Extended in Egypt as Turmoil Continues|url=http://en.rian.ru/world/20110130/162383449.html|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[RIA Novosti]]|date=30 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|last=Egypt|first=guardian.co.uk|title=Egyptian Protests â Timeline for the Weekend's Events|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jan/30/egypt-saturday-events-timeline|accessdate=31 January 2011|work=[[The Guardian]] |date=30 January 2011}}</ref> as security and army personnel left Tahrir Square.
  â
[[File:EAF Mi-17 over Cairo.jpg|thumb|left|An Egyptian Air Force [[Mi-17]] circling over Tahrir Square]]
  â   â
Hundreds of thousands continued to protest in Egyptian cities, including 250,000 protesters in Cairo alone.<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/watch_now|title=Live Stream â Watch Now|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/30/live-blog-311-egypt-protests|title=Live Blog 31/1 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> A protester was shot dead in [[Abu Simbel]] and extra troops were also moved to guard the [[Suez Canal]].<ref name="aljazeera1" /> For the first time during protests, there were pro-Mubarak protests of at least 1,000 people, mostly from the neighbourhood watch groups.<!--from tv--> Mohammed ElBaradei again joined thousands of protesters in Tahrir Square. He told the crowd, "What we have begun cannot go back", referring to the previous days of anti-government protests. The [[National Association for Change]], an [[umbrella group]] that contains several opposition movements including the Muslim Brotherhood and pro-democracy groups, chose ElBaradei to negotiate with Mubarak.
  â   â
Since police forces disappeared from Cairo, and the military took key positions there<!-- [date] -->, the degree of connection between the military and the current system (government, economic circles) and its position became critical. However, senior Egyptian generals led by Tantawi held back the military,<ref>{{cite web|author=David Costello ANALYSIS |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/ipad/nation-locked-in-a-deadly-stalemate/story-fn6ck51p-1225997761161 |title=Nation Locked in a Deadly Stalemate |work=[[The Courier-Mail]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> as the army as a whole stated its understanding of the legitimate rights of the "great people of Egypt", its will to not use violence against pacific protesters, and its wish for democratic transition.<ref>{{cite web|title=Egypt Braces for Massive Protest|work=[[BBC News]]|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12331520|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=Nakhoul|first=Samia|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/01/31/idINIndia-54544320110131|title=Mubarak Offers Talks, Pushed by Army, US, Protests|work=[[Reuters]]|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> The army released a statement saying:
  â
{{quote|"The armed forces will not resort to use of force against our great people. Your armed forces, who are aware of the legitimacy of your demands and are keen to assume their responsibility in protecting the nation and the citizens, affirms that freedom of expression through peaceful means is guaranteed to everybody."<ref>{{Cite news|last=Nakhoul|first=Samia|title=Update 1 â Egypt Army: Will Not Use Violence Against Citizens|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70U2JC20110131|work=[[Reuters]]|date=31 January 2011}}</ref>}}
  â   â
Reports emerged of several major prisons across the country being attacked, and law and order rapidly deteriorated across most of Egypt.<ref>[http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html ''Al Jazeera English'' coverage of events].</ref> Criminal violence continued in Cairo as looters burnt out the Arkadia shopping mall. [[Egypt Air]] cancelled all internal and outbound flights;<ref name="aljazeera1" /><ref name="wilsherline.net.uk">[http://www.wilsherline.net.uk/ "Egypt Air cancels all flights"]</ref> an inbound Egypt Air flight from London to Cairo was diverted to [[Athens]] because of an alleged bomb threat.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.comparecarhire.co.uk/news/egyptair-jet-diverted-to-athens-after-bomb-scare-53824639.html|title=EgyptAir Jet Diverted to Athens after Bomb Scare |publisher=Comparecarhire.co.uk|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Industrial strikes were also called in many cities, including Cairo.{{Which?|date=January 2011}}<!--from tv--> The Japanese firm [[Nissan]] had suspended production at its plant in Egypt to ensure employees' safety after anti-government protests, but the Korean owned [[Hyundai]]'s plant chose to continue working.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.just-auto.com/news/nissan-suspends-production-at-giza-plant_id108821.aspx|title=Egypt: Nissan Suspends Production at Giza Plant: Automotive News & Analysis|publisher=Just-auto.com|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[Zahi Hawass]], an internationally known [[archeologist]], was appointed by Mubarak to the newly created cabinet post of Minister of Antiquities during the cabinet shakeup on 31 January. Hawass said in a statement published on his personal blog that "the broken objects can all be restored, and we will begin the restoration process this week".<ref name="hawass-update">{{cite web|url=http://www.drhawass.com/blog/state-egyptian-antiquities-today-update|title=The State of Egyptian Antiquities Today: An Update|date=1 February 2011|work=Dr.hawass.com|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> In a ''[[New York Times]]'' interview he rejected comparisons with Iraq and Afghanistan and said that antiquities were being safeguarded.<ref name="Taylor">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02antiquities.html|title=Egyptian Official, Zahi Hawass, Says Antiquities Are Secure|last=Taylor|first=Kate|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The New York Times]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> [[Luis Ayala]], the secretary-general of the [[Socialist International]] said that the NDP was expelled because:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.socialistinternational.org/images/dynamicImages/files/Letter%20NDP.pdf|title=To the General Secretary of the National Democratic Party, Egypt|publisher=Socialist International|accessdate=2010-02-06}}</ref>
  â
<blockquote>The use of violence, with scores dead and injured, is totally incompatible with the policies and principles of any social democratic party anywhere in the world. Consequently, we consider that a party in government that does not listen, that does not move and that does not immediately initiate a process of meaningful change in these circumstances, cannot be a member of the Socialist International. We are, as of today, ceasing the membership of the NDP, however we remain determined to cooperate with all the democrats in Egypt striving to achieve an open, democratic, inclusive and secular state.</blockquote>
  â   â
===1 February â March of the Millions===
  â
[[File:Millionmarchtahrirsquare.jpg|thumb|Tahrir Square during the March of the Millions]]
  â   â
Opposition leaders called for a million-strong march dubbed '''"March of the Millions"'''<ref>{{clarify|date=February 2011|reason=article in german. at minimum, needs english translation of headline appended to "trans_title" field}} {{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/multimedia/bilder/kairo206.html |title=Marsch der Millionen: In Kairo marschieren die Massen gegen Mubarak|work=[[Tagesschau (Germany)|Tagesschau]]|trans_title=|language=[[German language|German]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> (literally the "March of One Million", from the Arabic {{lang|ar|ÙØ³ÙØ±Ø© ÙÙÙÙÙ}} ''masÄ«rat milyÅn'') from Cairo's Tahrir Square to the [[Heliopolis Palace|Presidential Palace]] in [[Heliopolis (Cairo suburb)|Heliopolis]] on 1 February.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2011/01/31/3126194.htm|title=Egypt Protesters Call for Million-Man March|publisher=Abc.net.au|date=|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title='Mega Protest' Planned in Egypt|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=31 January 2011|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/01/20111316148317175.html|accessdate=31 January 2011}}</ref> Egyptian security forces fortified Mubarak's presidential palace with coils of barbed wire to ensure that the protesters can not get there.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.irishtimes.com/newspaper/opinion/2011/0202/1224288768049.html|title=West Has Little To Fear from Arab Populism|author=Staunton, Denis|date=2 February 2011|work=[[The Irish Times]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
According to the Egyptian government media, the number of the protesters in Cairo numbered in the thousands. The BBC reported the number of protesters in Tahrir Square ranged from "more than 100,000 to some 250,000 â the square's maximum capacity."<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 "Live Update at 15:44: Huge Protests Fan Egypt Unrest"]. ''[[BBC News]]''. 1 February 2011.</ref> Egyptian security forces stated that 500,000 people participated in the protests in Cairo alone.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/aegyptenprotest120.html |title=Ãgypten: Mubarak verzichtet auf weitere Amtszeit |language={{de icon}} |publisher=tagesschau.de |date= |accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref> According to ''Al Jazeera'', over one million protesters gathered in central Cairo by the afternoon, a number growing to around 2 million later in the day.<ref>{{Cite news|work=[[Ynetnews]]|last=Shezaf|first=Tsur|title=A Million People Protest in Egypt|date=1 February 2011|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4022504,00.html|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[File:Cairo protestors in prayer - 1FEB2011.jpg|thumb|left|Demonstrators in Tahrir Square at [[salah|prayer]]]]
  â   â
Similar protests occurred across Egypt with hundreds of thousands protesting in Alexandria, and an estimated 250,000 protesting in Sinai<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/20112113115442982.html|title=Protesters Flood Egypt Streets|work=[[Al Jazeera English]]|date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/01/egypt-protests-live-updates|title=Egypt Protests â Live Updates|work=[[The Guardian]]}}</ref> and [[Suez]]<ref>{{cite web|author=Aneja, Atul|url=http://www.hindu.com/2011/02/02/stories/2011020263100100.htm |title=Unprecedented Show of People Power at Egypt's Tahrir Square |work=[[The Hindu]] |date=2 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> marking the largest mobilisation in the then eight day old protest. Meanwhile, a virtual "March of Millions" was launched on Facebook with the goal of reaching one million voices in support of the march.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.facebook.com/event.php?eid=126197157451259|title=Niet Compatibele Browser|publisher=[[Facebook]]|date=|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The United Nations human rights chief [[Navi Pillay]] announced that there were reports that more than 300 people had died in the violence with up to 3,000 injured, although stressed that these reports remain unconfirmed.<ref name="300 Killed">{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://www.news24.com/Africa/News/300-killed-so-far-in-Egypt-protests-20110201|title='300 Killed' So Far in Egypt Protests|publisher=[[South African Press Association]] (via ''[[News24]]'')|date=18 December 2010|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> Meanwhile banks are closed, making it difficult for people to get cash to buy food; for those that have money, prices are skyrocketing as consumers flood the few open stores.<ref>{{cite web|last=Galal |first=Ola |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-01/egyptians-face-soaring-food-prices-by-day-looters-at-night-amid-turmoil.html |title=Egyptians Face Food Inflation by Day, Looters by Night |work=[[Bloomberg]] |date= |accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref> [[Recep Tayyip Erdogan]], Turkey's Prime Minister urged Mubarak to meet his people's "desire for change".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/01/31/live-blog-feb-1-egypt-protests|title=Turkey's Prime Minister Weighs in on the Crisis|work=[[Al Jazeera]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=1 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
[[File:Cairo female protesters with colorful signs - 1FEB2011.jpg|thumb|Young protesters in Cairo. The middle sign reads: "Mubarak leave us and go look for someone else to gross out other than us."<ref>{{cite web|author=By monasosh Mona+ Add Contact |url=http://www.flickr.com/photos/89031137@N00/5410500494/ |title=IMG00743-20110201-1112 | Flickr - Photo Sharing! |publisher=Flickr |date=2011-02-01 |accessdate=2011-02-08}}</ref>]]
  â   â
In the late evening (11:00 pm local Egyptian time) President Mubarak proclaimed that he did not intend to run for another term in the next election.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429076/channels/cnn |title=Mubarak Video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Mubarak said he would stay in office to ensure a peaceful transition to the next election, [[Egyptian presidential election, 2011|set for September 2011]], and promised to make political reforms. He also said that he would demand that Egyptian authorities pursue "outlaws" and "investigate those who caused the security disarray." Mubarak said that peaceful protests were transformed into "unfortunate clashes, mobilised and controlled by political forces that wanted to escalate and worsen the situation". He called upon the [[Parliament of Egypt|Egyptian parliament]] to change the limit terms of the presidency and to change the requirements to run for president. He also accepted the legal charges against the parliament members which means a great amount of the parliament members will be changed through the legal process."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE7102JP20110201?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true |title=Text â President Mubarak's Speech after Mass Protest |work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
In the past, Mubarak has said he will continue to serve Egypt until his last breath. In his speech on 1 February 2011 he said: ''"This dear nation... is where I lived, I fought for it and defended its soil, sovereignty and interests. On its soil I will die. History will judge me like it did others."''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12301713 |title=Profile: Hosni Mubarak |work=[[BBC News]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Crowds continued protesting in Tahrir Square, demanding that the president step down.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.charter.net/video/play/429085/channels/cnn |title=Crowd video|publisher=Charter.net |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121191413252982.html |title=Defiant Mubarak Vows To Finish Term |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> There were reports that Mubarak's proclamation came after President Barack Obama's special envoy, [[Frank G. Wisner]], told Mubarak the U.S. saw his presidency at an end and urged him to prepare for an orderly transition to real democracy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110201/D9L48QIO0.html|title=Obama envoy told Mubarak tenure coming to a close|accessdate=2011-02-05|publisher=myway}}</ref>
  â
{{clear}}
  â   â
===2 February â Camel Battle===
  â
[[File:Camels_in_Tahrir_Square.Jpgâ|thumb|Camels in Tahrir Square]]
  â
[[File:'The March of Millions' - It's in our hands.png|thumb|upright|Protesters in Cairo next to Tahrir Square]]
  â
During the night of 1â2 February, Mubarak supporters and anti-Mubarak protesters clashed in Alexandria, where shots were reportedly fired into the air.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/01/live-blog-feb-2-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 2 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Government forces and the police also fired into the crowd in an attempt to disperse the protesters.<ref>{{Cite news|title=Clashes break out in Alexandria|publisher=''Presstv.ir''|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/163168.html|accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, many protesters from the previous day had remained in Tahrir Square overnight.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/02/world/middleeast/02scene.html?src=twrhp|title=Quiet Acts of Protest on a Noisy Day|work=[[The New York Times]]}}</ref>
  â   â
In the morning, internet access had been partially restored and the night-time curfew was eased, running from 5:00 pm to 7:00 am instead of 3:00 pm to 8:00 am.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
  â
<ref>{{cite web|last=Cowie |first=James |url=http://www.renesys.com/blog/2011/02/egypt-returns-to-the-internet.shtml |title=Egypt Returns To The Internet - Renesys Blog |publisher=Renesys.com |date=2011-02-02 |accessdate=2011-02-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12307698 |title=Egypt Unrest |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> By midday, the army was asking protesters to go home in order to stabilise the situation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.nationalpost.com/2011/02/02/goodspeed-analysis-only-the-egyptian-army-has-power-to-restore-stability/ |title=Goodspeed Analysis: Only the Egyptian Army Has Power To Restore Stability|work=[[National Post]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> State television then announced: "You have to evacuate Tahrir Square immediately. We've got confirmed information that violent groups are heading toward Tahrir Square carrying firebombs and seeking to burn the Square."<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
  â   â
The [[National Democratic Party (Egypt)|NDP]] sent many people to show support to Hosni Mubarak.<ref>{{cite news|author=Walt, Vivienne|url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2045328_2045333_2045720,00.html |title=Bloodshed as Mubarak Supporters Clash with Cairo Protesters â The Middle East in Revolt |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Provocateurs came riding on horses and camels armed with swords, whips, clubs, stones, rocks, and pocket knives, attacked anti-government protesters in central Cairo,<ref>Ackerman, Spencer (2 February 2011). [http://www.wired.com/dangerroom/2011/02/horses-camels-rocks-molotovs-egypts-thug-tech/?utm_source=feedburner&utm_medium=feed&utm_campaign=Feed%3A+WiredDangerRoom+%28Blog+-+Danger+Room%29 "Horses, Camels, Rocks, Molotovs: Egypt's Thug Tech"] ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{Cite news|title=Mubarak Supporters, Protesters Clash in Egypt|author=|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/41383377/ns/world_news-mideast/n_africa/|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Clashes Erupt in Cairo Between Mubarak's Allies and Foes|date=2 February 2011|url=http://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/03/world/middleeast/03egypt.html|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> including Tahrir Square<ref>{{Cite video|date=2 February 2011|title=Camels & Horses Storm into Tahrir Square as Protesters Clash in Cairo|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=YXwKqmDmuDs|work=[[RT (TV network)|RT]]|accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> in what was later known as the (''Battle of Jamal'' or ''Battle of the Camel'')<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12369422|title=Egyptian media: State misinformation amid the protests?|work=[[BBC News]]|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> ({{lang-ar|ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ}}).<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?id=384976|title=Ø¨ÙØ§ÙØ§ (ÙÙÙØ¹Ø© Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙ) ÙÙ Ø§ÙÙØªØ­Ù Ø§ÙÙØµØ±Ù Ø§ÙØ¬Ø¯ÙØ¯|work=Shorouk News|date=4 February 2011|accessdate=9 February 2011}}</ref> Security officials were witnessed bribing ordinary citizens into attacking protesters.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> Some of the Pro-Mubarak supporters were reportedly off-duty and [[undercover]] police.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators? |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Al Jazeera's live reporting showed that Mubarak supporters were carrying police IDs amidst clashes and that gunfire was heard in Tahrir Square.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
  â   â
[[Molotov cocktails]] were also used on anti-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.yahoo.com/s/ap/20110202/ap_on_re_mi_ea/ml_egypt |title=Chaos in Cairo as Mubarak Backers, Opponents Clash|work=[[Yahoo! News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> some landing on the grounds of the Egyptian Museum.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/02/egypt-protests-live-updates#block-66 |title=Egypt protests - Wednesday 2 February |work=The Guardian |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> Pro-Mubarak supporters were filmed dropping stones and firebombs from buildings to demonstrators on the ground. Five people have been reported killed and 836 people were taken to hospitals according the Health minister of Egypt.<ref>{{cite web|author=|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/world/67633/five-dead-as-shots-fired-during-cairo-clashes |title=Five Dead as Shots Fired During Cairo Clashes |work=[[Radio New Zealand]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> There were also clashes in Alexandria<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12345656 |title=Egypt Unrest: Deadly Clashes Rock Cairo's Tahrir Square |work=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and unrest in Port Said.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> ''CNN'' interviewed a few anaylsts who suggested a strategy of "hired muscle" has been tried-and-tested at numerous times in the past by the Mubarak regime, suggesting it could be the same this time despite Interior Ministry denials.<ref>{{cite web|author=[[Staff writer]]|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/africa/02/02/egypt.pro.mubarak/ |title=Who Are the Pro-Mubarak Demonstrators?|work=[[CNN]]|date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Journalists were also attacked by the pro-Mubarak activists.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/02/02/anderson-cooper-attacked-punched-egypt_n_817352.html |title=Anderson Cooper Attacked, Punched in the Head by Pro-Mubarak Mob in Egypt |work=[[The Huffington Post]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/worldnews/africaandindianocean/egypt/8288167/Egypt-protests-live.html |title=Egypt Protests: Live |work=[[The Daily Telegraph]] |date=28 January 2011 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> Western media suggested the possibility of Egypt descending into civil war as violence between the two sides escalated, leaving over a thousand injured.<ref>Beaumont, Peter; Shenker, Jack. [http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/03/egyptian-army-disperses-mubarak-supporters "Egyptian Army Disperses Mubarak Supporters from Bridge"]. ''[[The Guardian]]''. Retrieved 3 February 2011.</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.sky.com/skynews/Home/World-News/Egypt-Crisis-Violence-Breaks-Out-Between-Pro-And-Anti-Mubarak-Supporters-In-Tahrir-Square-Cairo/Article/201102115920969?lpos=World_News_Carousel_Region_0&lid=ARTICLE_15920969_Egypt_Crisis%3A_Violence_Breaks_Out_Between_Pro_And_Anti-Mubarak_Supporters_In_Tahrir_Square%2C_Cairo |title=Egypt Crisis: Violence Breaks Out Between Pro And Anti-Mubarak Supporters In Tahrir Square, Cairo |work=[[Sky News]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4023068,00.html |title=Civil War Underway in Egypt?|work=[[Ynetnews]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref><ref>Al-Shalchi, Hadeel; El Deeb, Sarah (2 February 2011). [http://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/crisis-in-egypt/latest-news/hundreds-injured-one-dead-after-mubarak-protesters-and-supporters-clash/article1891913/page2/ "Hundreds Injured, One Dead after Mubarak Protesters and Supporters Clash"]. ''[[Associated Press]]'' (via ''[[The Globe and Mail]]''). Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref><ref>[http://www.cbc.ca/world/story/2011/02/02/egypt-mubarak-military.html "Egyptian Clashes Leave 3 Dead, Hundreds Hurt â Demonstrations Continue in Cairo Despite Curfew"]. 2 February 2011''[[CBC News]]''. Retrieved 2 February 2011.</ref>
  â   â
{{External media
  â
| video1 = {{YouTube|mMbAx_fYVcs|Scenes of clashes in Tahrir Square}}
  â
| video2 = {{YouTube|xcjJsg8AD2g|Raw Video: Dramatic New Images of Cairo Violence}}
  â
| video3 = {{YouTube|YXwKqmDmuDs|Camels & horses storm into Tahrir Square as protesters clash in Cairo}}
  â
| video4 = {{YouTube|VqydgpyVNKY|Wednesday night intense battle}}
  â
| video5 = {{YouTube|dVvUZmNrAHA|Protesters Arrest Bus driver who had driven in to them}}
  â
}}
  â   â
[[UN Secretary General]] Ban Ki-moon condemned the violence and reiterated calls for reform,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE71120F20110202 |title=Update 2 â UN's Ban Urges Reform Not Repression in Egypt|work=[[Reuters]] |date=9 February 2009 |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â
while EU foreign policy chief Catherine Ashton also said that the violence must stop and that Mubarak needs to be more explicit in showing the people what changes would happen.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
  â   â
UK Prime Minister David Cameron and the White House condemned the violence, and the US State Department also called for restraint amidst the violence.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> US President Obama also said that the transition "must be meaningful, it must be peaceful and it must begin now".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/POLITICS/02/01/us.egypt.obama/index.html|title=Obama says Egypt's transition 'must begin now'|work=[[CNN]] |date=2 February 2011 |accessdate=13 February 2011}}</ref> German Foreign Minister Guido Westerwelle and French President Nicolas Sarkozy asserted the right to march peacefully, while Turkish Premier Recep Tayyip Erdogan called for an enhanced to democratisations. Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu expressed concern over a new government saying: "I am convinced that the forces that want to bring change and democratization in Egypt will also enhance peace between Israel and the Arab world. But we are not there yet. The struggle has not been decided...We need to do everything to make sure that peace endures."<ref>{{cite web|author=Alan Silverleib |url=http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/02/02/egypt.world.reaction/ |title=World Leaders Denounce Attacks on Egyptian Protesters |work=[[CNN]] |date= |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Mubarak rejects international calls to step aside. Finance Minister Samir Radwan said the government would be "open to discussion with all shades of political opinions". The army had earlier broadcast a message on television: ''...You began by going out to express your demands and you are the ones capable of restoring normal life.''
  â
[[Ali Gomaa]], the [[Grand Mufti]] of Egypt, says: "I greet President Mubarak who offered dialogue and responded to the demands of the people. Going against legitimacy is [[Haram|forbidding]]. This is an invitation for chaos. We support stability. What we have now is a blind chaos leading to a civil war. I call on all parents to ask their children to stay home." A former general who was a part of the intelligence services said that Mubarak would have no qualms about "setting the whole country on fire."<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" />
  â   â
Mohammed ElBaradei called on the army to intervene.<ref name="aljazbloglive2feb" /> He also said Mubarak should be given a "safe exit" for Friday's "Departure Day."<ref>{{cite web|author=John Lyons, Cairo |url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/news/world/hosni-mubarak-must-go-by-friday-says-mohamed-elbaradei/story-e6frg6so-1225998404724 |title=Hosni Mubarak Must Go by Friday, Says Mohamed ElBaradei |work=[[The Australian]] |date= |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref> and that "Today's violence is again an indication of a criminal regime that has lost any commonsense. When the regime tries to counter a peaceful demonstration by using thugs ... there are few words that do justice to this villainy and I think it can only hasten that regime's departure."<ref>{{cite web|author=Staff reporters|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/feb/02/egypt-revolution-turns-ugly|title=Egypt's Revolution Turns Ugly as Mubarak Fights Back|work=[[The Guardian]]|date= 2 February 2011|accessdate= 2 February 2011}}</ref> A coalition of the opposition parties agreed to hold talks with the newly formed government. However, Mohamed ElBaradei and the Muslim Brotherhood stressed they would not talk to any government representative, including Vice President Omar Suleiman, until Mubarak's resignation.<ref>{{cite web|last=Issacharoff |first=Avi |url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/news/is-mubarak-at-the-end-of-his-tether-1.340934 |title=Is Mubarak at the End of His Tether?|work=[[Haaretz]]|date=28 January 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
===3 February===
  â
[[File:A baby Egyptian protesting the government.png|thumb|A baby waving the [[flag of Egypt]] in Tahrir Square]]
  â
On 2â3 February, 13 people were killed and 1,200 injured, according to the Egyptian health ministry.<ref>{{cite news|title=Egypt protests - live updates|url=http://www.guardian.co.uk/news/blog/2011/feb/03/egypt-protests-live-updates|newspaper=The Guardian|date=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
In Cairo, a standoff took place in front of the Egyptian Museum in the early morning hours with rocks and petrol bombs reportedly flying. Large-caliber shots were reportedly fired in the air by the army to keep opposing factions at bay. There was a heavy police presence at the museum following the standoff. Anti-government protesters were seen banging on metal railings while rocks were thrown at them.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/02/live-blog-feb-3-egypt-protests |date=2 February 2011 |title=Live Blog 3 Feb - Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Protests continued in Alexandria and Mansoura, where ''Al Jazeera'' suggested up to a million people marched.<ref name="aljazbloglive3feb">{{cite web|url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/middle-east/2011/02/02/live-blog-feb-3-egypt-protests |title=Live Blog Feb 3 â Egypt Protests |work=[[Al Jazeera]]|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> In Cairo, Egyptian army tanks cleared a highway overpass from which pro-Mubarak protesters had been hurling rocks and Molotov cocktails onto the anti-Mubarak protesters. On the streets below, hundreds of armed soldiers lined up between the two factions, pushing the pro-Mubarak protesters back and blocking the main hotspots in front of the Egyptian Museum and at other entrances to the square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110203/D9L5DANO0.html |title=Cairo square chaos intensifies, violence spreads |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Violence was reported to have been perpetrated by police.<ref name="bloomberg3feb2">{{cite web|last=Mazen |first=Maram |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-04/-you-will-be-lynched-egyptian-policeman-tells-reporters-first-person.html |title=``You Will Be Lynched,'' Egyptian Policeman Tells Reporters: First Person |publisher=Bloomberg|accessdate=2011-02-05}}</ref>
  â   â
With banks closed and not due to open for three more days,<ref name="bloomberg2">{{cite web|last=Namatalla |first=Ahmed A |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-02-03/egypt-s-opposition-rejects-mubarak-talks-urges-supporters-to-hold-ground.html |title=Egypt's Anti-Mubarak Protesters Vow to Hold Ground |work=[[Bloomberg]]|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> cash-starved Egyptians were being offered food and money to side against the anti-Mubarak protesters in Tahrir Square.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110203/D9L5DTJ00.html |title=Cash-Starved Egyptians Turn on Each Other |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
Shahira Amin resigned from her position as deputy head of [[Nile TV]], citing its coverage of the protests; she spoke live to Al Jazeera and to CNN. She said: "I walked out yesterday. I can't be part of the propaganda machine; I am not going to feed the public lies."<ref>[http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2011/02/07/eveningnews/main7327273.shtml "Egyptian State TV Finally Airs Voice of Dissent"] by Mark Strassmann - ''CBS News.'' Retrieved 11 February 2011.</ref> Many international journalists in Egypt to cover the protests were detained, beaten, shouted at or threatened by pro-Mubarak protesters,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://apnews.myway.com//article/20110203/D9L503U80.html |title=Journalists Attacked, Detained in Egypt |publisher=Apnews.myway.com |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ca.news.yahoo.com/canadian-cameraman-severely-beaten-egypt-report-20110202-134200-295.html |title=Canadian Cameraman Severely Beaten in Egypt: report |publisher=Ca.news.yahoo.com |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> as were numerous Egyptian bloggers and activists including [[Wael Abbas]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://abcnews.go.com/Blotter/wael-abbas-arrested-egypt/story?id=12834725 |title=Egyptian Blogger Who Posted Videos of Police Torture Is Arrested, Released |last=Cole |first=Matthew |coauthors=Mark Schone |work=ABC News |date=4 February 2011 |accessdate=5 February 2011}}</ref> Two Al Jazeera reporters were attacked as they arrived from the airport<ref>{{cite web|url=http://gulfnews.com/news/region/egypt/new-clashes-as-egypt-protesters-push-back-rivals-1.756374 |title=Egypt VP Says Violence Result of 'Conspiracy' |work=[[Gulf News]] |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> while three others were arrested<ref>{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201123165214813586.html|title=Call To Free ''Al Jazeera'' Journalists|work=[[Al Jazeera English]] |date=3 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref> and later released.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/03/us-jazeera-arrests-idUSTRE71285020110203|title=''Al Jazeera'' Says Journalists Released in Egypt|work=[[Reuters]]|date=3 February 2011|accessdate=4 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
The Prosecutor General decided to prevent former ministers and government officials Ahmed Abdel Aziz Ahmed Ezz, Mohamed Zuhair Mohamed Waheed Garana, Ahmed Alaa El Din Maghraby, Habib Ibrahim El Adly and a number of others from traveling outside the country. He also froze their bank accounts, pending the return of security and stability, and the establishment of the investigative and supervisory authorities and investigative procedures to identify and investigate criminal and administrative responsibilities in all of these cases.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.shorouknews.com/ContentData.aspx?ID=384682 |title=Attorney General Decides To Prevent Ahmed Ezz, the Number of Ministers and Former Officials from Traveling Abroad.|publisher=shorouknews.com |accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>
  â   â
{{quotebox|"I was very unhappy about yesterday. I do not want to see Egyptians fighting each other...I don't care what people say about me. Right now I care about my country, I care about Egypt...I would never run away. I will die on this soil."|Hosni Mubarak<ref name="CA">{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/egypt-abc-news-christiane-amanpour-exclusive-interview-president/story?id=12833673 |title=Mubarak: 'If I Resign Today There Will Be Chaos' |work=[[ABC News]]|date=3 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref>||width = 40%}}
  â   â
In an interview with [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]'s [[Christiane Amanpour]], Mubarak said that he was "fed up" with being in power but would not resign because he did not want Egypt to descend into a chaos in which the Muslim Brotherhood would be the beneficiaries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12361948 |title=Mubarak 'Fears Chaos If He Quits' |work=[[BBC News]] |date= 3 February 2011|accessdate=3 February 2011}}</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman also said, in the same interview, that the Egyptian people do not have a culture of democracy and that an Islamic current is pushing young people to protest.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://abcnews.go.com/watch/this-week/SH559082/VD55110136/this-week-206-what-happens-next-in-egypt|title=What Happens Next in Egypt?|date= 6 February 2011|accessdate=8 February 2011}}</ref> Vice President Omar Suleiman, in an interview broadcast on state television, re-asserted that "The president will not go for another term nor any member of his family including his son.
